comments.author: PrincessSarah090288

comments.text:
+Taqifsha Nanen Julian Bond, civil rights legend, really says it best, "To 
be blind to color is to be blind to the consequences of color," (i.e., 
racism). The biggest problem that we have to get over is "white denial," 
though, and I say that as someone who has studied that for a long time. 

Even in the early 60s, BEFORE the Civil Rights Act was passed, Gallup Polls 
found that 2 out of 3 white Americans thought that black Americans had 
FULLY equal opportunity. 

As an African man I'm saying, if you don't TALK to children ABOUT 
RACISM(White Supremacy or African Supremacy), both PAST AND PRESENT, they 
grow up — they can look around and see the disparities — they can see that 
who has what is often about color, who lives where is often about color — 
if you don't provide the context for that, you know what happens, those 
kids grow up, according to the research, to believe that those disparities 
are A) natural, which is a dangerous thought, or B) that the folks on the 
bottom are there because...they don't try hard enough, their bad people, 
they aren't as smart as the rest of us whites.

Carthage was founded in the 9th century B.C. on the Gulf of Tunis. From the 
6th century onwards, it developed into a great trading empire covering much 
of the Mediterranean and was home to a brilliant civilization. In the 
course of the long Punic Wars, Carthage occupied some of Rome’s territories 
before finally being destroyed by its rival in 146 B.C.
In his book, World’s Great Men of Color, Volume 1, history scholar J.A. 
Rogers asserts, “The Carthaginians were descendants of the Phoenicians, a 
Negroid people, and that in fact until the rise of the doctrine of white 
superiority, Hannibal was traditionally known as a Black man.”
Today, many encyclopedias classify the Carthaginians as whites or Semites, 
but ancient Greek and Roman eyewitness accounts paint a different 
picture.The indigenous peoples of Carthage were called the Afers.  Ancient 
Roman poet Vergil in his poem “Moretum” speaks of a woman from the Afer 
[Afar/Afra] race. He says of her:
“And all her figure proves her native land. Her hair was curly, thick her 
lips, and dark her color.”
In Library of  History Book XX, Greek historian Diodorus mentions a Greek 
lieutenant named Agathocles, who defeated a people in the area of 
present-day Tunisia, who were the same hue as Ethiopians.
The eyewitness accounts are corroborated by physical anthropology. L. 
Bertholon and E. Chantre, both well-noted French anthropologists, 
documented their examination of skeletons throughout North Africa in all 
periods. They note that the remains of both upper and lower class 
individuals of ancient North Africa were representative of the Negroid race.

common white defense mechanism when faced with racial issues *
 -bring up how slavery is over
 -bring up how none of their ancestors owned slaves
 -point fingers at other races
-creates some fabricated oppression towards whites
-go on a reverse racism rant
- Throwing out random FBI statistics of black crime
 -Makes statements with no factual basis to their statement like "black 
people want free handouts", when in reality hard work and laziness is not 
exclusive to a particular race or gender.
QUOTE "All the Egyptians," wrote de Volney, "have a bloated face, puffed-up 
eyes, flat nose, thick lips – in a word, the true face of the mulatto. I 
was tempted to attribute it to the climate, but when I visited the Sphinx, 
its appearance gave me the key to the riddle. On seeing that head, 
typically Negro in all its features,remarkable passage where Herodotus 
says: ' As for me, I judge the Colchians to be a colony of the Egyptians 
because, like them, they are black with woolly hair... "When I visited the 
Sphinx, I could not help thinking that the figure of that monster furnished 
the true solution to the enigma(of how the modern Egyptians came to have 
their 'mulatto' appearance) "In other words, the ancient Egyptians were 
true Negroes of the same type as all native-born Africans. That being so, 
we can see how their blood, mixed for several centuries with that of the 
Greeks and Romans, must have lost the intensity of its original color, 
while retaining nonetheless the imprint of its original mold. "Just think," 
de Volne declared incredulously, "that this race of Black men, today our 
slave and the object of our scorn, is the very race to which we owe our 
arts, sciences, and even the use of speech! Just imagine, finally, that it 
is in the midst of people who call themselves the greatest friends of 
liberty and humanity that one has approved the most barbarous slavery, and 
questioned whether Black men have the same kind of intelligence as whites!" 
END QUOTE

comments.text:
The people who created the Pharaonic Empire, came from the West(nothing to 
do with Lybia) and East(nothing to do with Middle-East) of Egypt they left 
that place due to changing weather and the fact that they couldn't plant 
their agriculture from June till September anymore (hottest months in 
Egypt), plus at that particular time 4000 BC, the country possessed many 
Oasis within the desert.
 The colour that they used to use to represent men was 
acre=reddish/brown(not black) and light/yellow for women that you can still 
find today. Those informations, came from Egyptologist at the American 
university and the Egyptian Museum in Cairo that i personally met ! 

Also, at that time Nubians lived as well in Egypt but in the South between 
Assouan and Abu Simbel such as Sub-Saharians in Moroccco until Lybia. 

I didn't say that Native Egytians were Arabs did i !???

comments.text:
People who think that the ancient Egyptians were black are wrong,especially 
those of you who think that Cleopoatra was it. She was actually of Greek 
heritage (the Ptolomaic dynasty started with Ptolemy who was one of 
Alexander the Great's generals and who took over Egypt after Alexander's 
death). The pharaohs (as well as up to 25% of the ancient Egyptians) 
practised close family inter-marriages because they believed it would keep 
their blood lines pure! And when it comes to blacks in ancient Egypt, they 
were most likely Nubian (depicted as black in contrast to brown or red on 
ancient reliefs). In other words, not Egyptian! What does Africa have to do 
with anything? Africa is a continent, lines drawn on paper, made up of man! 
It could just as well have been so that Spain or Turkey or the whole of the 
Middle East belonged to it! Doesn't mean a thing! There are records that 
identify the ancient Libyans as blond and blue eyed. The Tuareg and other 
indigenous Berber populations of northern Africa like the Kabyle people are 
also white (excluding the ones who intermixed with black slaves etc). These 
people lived there a long time before the Arab invasions and still exist to 
this day. Arabs did not make the ancient Egyptians white! These are all 
facts that can be easily googled! I understand the desire to revolt against 
"white" colonialism and mediatization of history but some of you need to 
get your facts straight first. The lack of knowledge is embarrassing.
comments.author: BlindMute Deaf

comments.author: raphael fallone

comments.text:
Just to chill everyone out:

1. 'in order to African u have to be black so ancient Egyptians were 
actually black African people'. Flawless argument.

2. There aren't and won't be any records left of what ancient Egyptians 
looked like. Nor do we have written music by them. Unlike many ancient 
people like the Sumerians, Egyptian archives were all written on papyrus, a 
lot of which didn't make it to modern archeologists. Traces of Egyptian 
heritage and culture have descended to the Coptics. The liturgical music of 
the Coptic Christian Church is believed to somewhat reflect ancient 
Egyptian music, and it is also believed that the closest we will ever see 
to ancient Egyptian facial features are that of their descendants, modern 
'coptic' people. After centuries of cultural mixing, they may look just 
'middle eastern' to those who have done little travelling there, but 
there's something about the 'look' which is still different from other 
middle eastern cultures, and NOT that they look more 'black'.

comments.author: gohanchan60

comments.text:
+gohanchan60 The Sai is based on the Indian Trishula which is a common 
symbol in Hinduism (The God Shiva uses The Trishula, or South Asian 
Trident, as his main weapon similar to how the Greek God Poseidon uses a 
Trident as his main weapon). Tridents made their way to the rest of Asia & 
The Middle East via India so it may not be that farfetched to consider a 
Sai being used in Ancient Egyptian Culture. It's also not too farfetched to 
consider that some cultures may have had Tridents heavily influenced by The 
Sai or some other popular Trident.
comments.author: chilvari
